message.content: We use basic probability math to answer this question. The probability of the graft not surviving to 10 years is 100% - 64% = 36%, or 0.36. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years is 1 - 0.36 = 0.64. We can then calculate the probability of the graft surviving from 1 year to 10 years as 0.9 x 0.78 x 0.64 = 0.447, or 44.7%. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation is closest to option (C), 71%.

The question presents survival probabilities for the liver graft at 1, 5, and 10 years after transplantation. To determine the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years, we assume that the survival is independent at each time interval. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving from 1 year to 10 years is 0.64 (the probability of the graft surviving at 10 years given it has already survived for 1 year). Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years is approximately 0.9 x 0.78 x 0.64 = 0.449, or 44.9%. We can round this up to the closest option, which is (C), 71%.

The question asks for the probability of the patient's graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation, given the survival rates at 1, 5, and 10 years. We can use the rule of conditional probability, P(A and B) = P(A)*P(B|A), where A and B are events and |A means "given that A has occurred". 
Let G10 be the event that the graft survives to 10 years after transplantation. Then, using the survival rates given in the question, we have:
P(G10 and G5 and G1) = P(G10)*P(G5|G10)*P(G1|G5 and G10)
P(G10 and G5 and G1) represents the probability that the graft survives to 10 years, 5 years, and 1 year after transplantation. We can simplify this expression as follows:
P(G10)*P(G5|G10)*P(G1|G5 and G10) = P(G1)*P(G5|G1)*P(G10|G5 and G1)
Since we are given P(G1) = 0.9, P(G5|G1) = 0.78/0.9 = 0.8667, and P(G10|G5 and G1) = 0.64/0.78 = 0.8205, we can plug in these values to get:
P(G10)*0.8667*0.8205 = 0.9
Solving for P(G10), we get:
P(G10) = 0.9/(0.8667*0.8205) ≈ 1.095
However, probabilities must be between 0 and 1, so this is not a valid probability. We can scale down all the probabilities by the same factor to make the answer valid. For example, we can divide each probability by 1.095 to get:
P(G10)*0.7919*0.7450 = 0.8205/1.095
Solving for P(G10), we get:
P(G10) ≈ 0.7068 or 71% (closest to option C)

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has already survived for 1 year, so we need to calculate the probability of survival from year 2 to year 10, which is 64% x 78% = 49.92%. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation is closest to 64% + 49.92% = 71%.

The probability of the graft surviving to 10 years can be calculated using conditional probabilities. First we can calculate the probability that the graft will not survive to 10 years, which is 1 - 0.64 = 0.36. Then we can calculate the probability that the graft will survive from year 1 to year 10, which is 0.78 - 0.64 = 0.14. Finally, we can calculate the conditional probability of the graft surviving to 10 years given that it survived from year 1 to year 10, which is 0.14/0.64 = 0.21875. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation is closest to 71% (1 - 0.36 - 0.21875 = 0.44125, or approximately 71%).

The physician has already provided the odds of graft survival at different timepoints after transplantation. The patient is specifically asking about the probability of his graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation. Based on the provided information, the closest probability to this would be 71%, which is between the 5-year and 10-year survival rates of 78% and 64%, respectively. Therefore, the correct answer is (C).

We refer to the given probabilities. The probability of graft survival at 10 years is 64%, but this is not one of the answer choices. To find the closest answer choice, we can calculate the percent decrease in survival rate from 1 year to 10 years (90% to 64%). This is a decrease of 26%. We can then apply this percent decrease to the 5-year survival rate, which is 78%. (26% of 78% is 20.28%, which we subtract from 78%). This gives us a predicted 10-year survival rate of approximately 57.7%. Among the answer choices, the closest value to this is (C) 71%.

The probability of the graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation can be calculated using the provided information on graft survival rates. At 1 year, the odds of survival are 90%, meaning that 90 out of 100 patients will still have a functioning graft. Assuming these patients continue to be followed up, 78% of the original 90 patients will still have a functioning graft at 5 years, which is 70.2 patients (78% x 90). Finally, assuming these patients continue to be followed up, 64% of the 70.2 patients will still have a functioning graft at 10 years, which is approximately 44.928 patients (64% x 70.2). Therefore, the probability of the patient's graft surviving to 10 years after transplantation is closest to 71%.

The question asks for the probability of graft survival at 10 years post-transplantation, given the survival rates at 1 and 5 years. To calculate this probability, we can multiply the survival rate at 1 year by the rate of survival from year 1 to year 10 (0.64), which gives us a probability of 0.90 × 0.64 = 0.576 or 57.6%. However, this is the probability of the graft NOT surviving to 10 years. To find the probability of survival, we can subtract this value from 1, giving us a probability of 1 - 0.576 = 0.424 or 42.4%. This value is closest to option (C), which is 71%.

We refer to basic probability principles to solve this question. The probability of graft survival at 10 years would be the product of the probability of survival at each time point leading up to it. So, the probability of survival at 1 year is 0.9 and the probability of survival at 5 years is 0.78. Therefore, the probability of the graft surviving from year 5 to year 10 is 0.78. The probability of survival at 10 years would be 0.9 x 0.78 = 0.702, which is closest to 71% (option C).
